{{Infobox Organization |name = Lake Ontario Waterkeeper |formation = 2001 |type = Environmental justice advocacy |headquarters = [[Toronto, Ontario]], [[Canada]] |language = [[English language|English]] |leader_title = President |leader_name = Mark Mattson |key_people = Krystyn Tully |budget = C$263,712 (2005) |website = http://waterkeeper.ca }} '''Lake Ontario Waterkeeper''' is a [[Toronto]]-based environmental justice [[advocacy group]] founded in 2001, with [[Lake Ontario]], the [[Great Lakes Basin]], and allied waterways at heart. It is a licensed member of the [[New York]]-based [[Waterkeeper Alliance]],<ref name=WALOW> {{cite web |url= http://www.waterkeeper.org/subsites/subcontact.aspx?userid=82 |accessdate= 2009-02-12 |title= Waterkeeper: Lake Ontario Waterkeeper: Contact Us |publisher= [[Waterkeeper Alliance]] }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> and a registered Canadian charity.<ref name=CRALOW> {{cite web |url= http://www.cra-arc.gc.ca/ebci/haip/srch/sec/SrchInput03Render-e?bn=862622750RR0001 |title= Canadian Registered Charities - Detail page |accessdate= 2009-02-12 |publisher= [[Canada Revenue Agency]] }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Lake Ontario Waterkeeper is led by President Mark Mattson, an environmental lawyer, and Vice President Krystyn Tully.<ref name="eye-pp"> {{cite news |url= http://www.eyeweekly.com/eye/issue/issue_05.22.03/news/beaches.php |accessdate= 2007-10-23 |title= Political pollution |publisher= [[Eye Weekly]] |date= May 22, 2003 |first= Edward |last= Keenan |coauthors= Prittie, Jennifier }}</ref><ref> {{cite news |title= From Chicago to Toronto, cities spilling waste into Great Lakes |publisher= Milwaukee Journal Sentinel |date= June 26, 2004 |url= http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=239659&format=print }}</ref><ref> {{cite news |title= Ships sweep toxic trash into our lake â€“ and feds just let it happen |publisher= Now Toronto |date= May 19, 2005 |url= http://www.nowtoronto.com/issues/2005-05-19/news_story.php}}</ref>
==Actions and initiatives== In Summer of 2001 LOW triggered a $250 Million Federal Government remediation plan at [[Port Granby]] near [[Port Hope, Ontario]]. The dump, was established by [[Eldorado Mining and Refining Limited]] (and now managed by [[Cameco Corp.]]).<ref name=Yachting> {{cite journal | last = McCutcheon | first = Duff | title = Mark Mattson, Lake Ontario Keeper | journal = Canadian Yachting | pages = 26, 27 | publisher = Kerrwil Publications Limited, Oct 2002 | date = October 1, 2007 | url = http://proquest.umi.com/pqdweb?did=347122521&sid=2&Fmt=3&clientId=61614&RQT=309&VName=PQD | id = 347122521 | issn = 03840999 | accessdate = 2007-10-23}}</ref> In 2005 LOW campaigned the City of [[Kingston, Ontario]] to disclose timely data about repeated sewage discharges into Lake Ontario.<ref>Kingston Whig-Standard (ON) - Final - 23 December 2005</ref> In 2006 LOW produced "Heart of A Lake" concert tour to several cities in [[Ontario, Canada]] ''blending activism with art''.<ref> {{cite news |publisher = Canada NewsWire |location = Ottawa |date = August 28, 2006 |pages = 1 |title = Gord Downie and Waterkeeper bring "Heart of A Lake" to Whitby, Port Hope, Kingston}}</ref> Starting in 2006 LOW started a campaign opposing the burning of tires by Lafarge operations in [[Bath, Ontario]].<ref>{{cite news |publisher= Kingston Whig-Standard |location = Ontario |date = September 12, 2007 |title = Lafarge review rolls on}}</ref> In 2007 LOW compelled the City of [[Toronto]] to disclose specific reasons why beaches are closed, and used the legal system to force the City to take responsibility.<ref name="eye-pp" /> Citing a "little-known provincial environmental guideline called F-5 that says municipalities must ensure that beaches are clean enough for swimming 95 per cent of the time." This builds on a 2006 LOW report "Investigating Municipal Beaches: Lessons from Bluffer's Park" which cited some beaches beaches were closed to swimming 42 per cent of the time.<ref name="eye-ctcb"> {{cite news |url= http://www.eyeweekly.com/eye/issue/issue_06.15.06/city/news.php |title= Calling the City's Bluff: One advocate says Toronto needs to stop making excuses and start cleaning up our beaches |first= Mark |last= Medley |publisher= Eye Weekly}}</ref>
In 2009, the organization launched '''Swim Drink Fish Music''', an online music club which features rare and exclusive tracks by Canadian musicians.<ref>[http://community.hour.ca/blogs/music_news/archive/2010/08/25/great-lake-swimmers-record-quot-ballad-of-a-fisherman-s-wife-quot-for-swim-drink-fish-music-club.aspx "Great Lake Swimmers Record 'Ballad of a Fisherman's Wife' for Swim Drink Fish Music Club"]. ''[[Hour (magazine)|Hour]]'', August 25, 2010.</ref>
==Notable supporters== *[[The Tragically Hip]] and particularly their frontman [[Gord Downie]]<ref>{{cite news |title= Stars align in Banff |publisher= Calgary Sun |date= January 18, 2007 |url=http://www.calgarysun.com/cgi-bin/publish.cgi?p=169265&x=articles&s=showbiz}}</ref><ref name=LiveShows>{{cite web |url= http://www.waterkeeper.ca/content/other/3_live_shows_raise_awareness_c.php |accessdate= 2007-10-23 |title= 3 live shows raise awareness, cash for Lake Ontario Watershed: Chris Brown, Barenaked Ladies, Sarah Harmer perform this week |author= Lake Ontario Waterkeeper |date= September 25, 2007 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071028205121/http://www.waterkeeper.ca/content/other/3_live_shows_raise_awareness_c.php <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-10-28}}</ref> *[[Sarah Harmer]], folk musician<ref name=LiveShows /><ref name="ca"> {{cite web |url=http://www.chartattack.com/news/44503/sarah-harmer-gord-downie-and-others-team-up-in-support-of-lake-ontario-waterkeeper |title= Sarah Harmer, Gord Downie And Others Team Up In Support Of Lake Ontario Waterkeeper |accessdate=2009-03-14 |first=Moya | last=Dillon | publisher=''[[Chart (magazine)|ChartAttack]]''}}</ref> *[[David Suzuki]], Canadian environmentalist and broadcaster.<ref name=LiveShows /> *[[Bruce Cockburn]], musician<ref name=LiveShows /> *[[Chris Brown (Canadian singer)|Chris Brown]], musician<ref name="ca" /> *[[Law Foundation of Ontario]]<ref>{{cite news |publisher= Canada NewsWire |location= Ottawa |date= June 6, 2007 |pages= 1 |title= The Law Foundation of Ontario expands support to public interest organizations}}</ref><ref>[http://www.law.utoronto.ca/documents/press_releases/05_06_LawFoundation.doc The Law Foundation of Ontario Selects Six Public Interest Organizations for Innovative Articling Fellowships]. Press Release. June 16, 2005.</ref>
